awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Computational Resources for Research in Computational and Systems Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal #:	12-29064
PI(s):		Camacho, Carlos J; Chong, Lillian T
Institution:	University of Pittsburgh
Title:		MRI/Acq.: Computational Resources for Research in Computational and Systems Biology

Project Proposed:
This project, acquiring a computational instrument, fosters interdisciplinary collaborations and training that promote breakthroughs in the biological sciences. The project is lead by the Department of Computational and Systems Biology (DCSB) in conjunction with the joint Ph.D. program between two institutions in the area: Pittsburgh and Carnegie Mellon Universities. The acquisition, a state-of-the-art 57-node 3392 core computing cluster, is dedicated to research and development of applications and the dissemination of new computational methods. The cluster supports the following research projects:
-	Novel molecular methods to access biological timescales of interest; 
-	Deep-sequencing technologies for high throughput ?omic? data collection; and, 
-	Methods to leverage high-resolution multi-modal biomedical images/videos in basic research.

Broader Impacts: 
Broader impacts should be felt both regionally and nationally. At the involved institutions, the research initiatives the incorporation of developed applications in teaching modules for use at local city high schools, as well as in undergraduate and graduate courses. Access to dedicated computational resources will provide valuable hands on experiences for students. More broadly, the software developed exploits the new computational resources that will be made available to other researchers nationwide.

por.por_cntn:
The MRI grant was used to purchase 24 computer nodes, 6 GPU nodes and 40 TB of disk space that are hosted at the Center for Simulation and Modeling - University of Pittsburgh. These nodes were dedicated for both performing research in a broad set of computational biology problems and training purposes.  The intellectual merit of the research performed with MRI resources included (a) the development of WESTPA, an open-source, highly scalable platform to carry out weighted ensemble simulations; (b) the implementation of a novel approach to determine clusters of co-functional genes based on the covariance of evolutionary rates (ERC) of protein coding genes across 33 mammalian genomes; and, (c) the improvement of docking and scoring methods, as well as teaching tutorials (zincpharmer.csb.pitt.edu/tdt), for virtual screening of small molecules affinities against a fix receptor. The TDT resource was used to support TECBio, a REU undergraduate research program, with hands-on experience in computational chemistry. The distribution and accessibility of the research and educational tools facilitated by the MRI are now incorporated in teaching modules in the PhD program in Computational Biology at the University of Pittsburgh and could also be incorporated in undergraduate and high school science courses. The latter together with the training opportunity provided for undergraduates, graduates and post docs were part of the broader impact of this research.
